author: sky.cactus
content: We need validators to stake so we can  punish them for failing to follow consensus rules after the fact.

author: m.kalinin
content: It doesn't sound like a fully functional consensus rule, rather a fork choice rule. One may manipulate burned ETH to induce reorgs with such fork choice rule.

author: pietjepuk
content: I agree it is complex and the likelihood of nothing happening, but disagree it should have been solved before mainnet launch. It's not backwards incompatible in any way no?

author: potuz
content: It pertains changing the semantics of deployed keys, that's inherently backwards incompatible unless we include yet a third set of keys for newly deployed validators. Whatever we do, we won't fix the situation for the already existing validators without breaking trust on the existing keys

author: pietjepuk
content: Breaking trust? I thought the whole point was that withdrawal credentials are the _owner_ of the funds (unlike the validator keys). Being able to initiate an exit doesn't really feel like breaking trust to me.

author: pietjepuk
content: For the other way around of validator keys changing withdrawal credentials (also brought up a lot) I agree with you; that's breaking trust assumptions.

author: potuz
content: It is, there are staking services that rely on the current meaning and functionality of keys. Take for example staked.us that uses the validators pubkey as returned from the staking-cli as a withdrawal BLS address

author: pietjepuk
content: I have no idea what you mean. What is a "withdrawal BLS address"?

author: potuz
content: There are two private pairs created for a BLS validator, a public/private validating key, the public part is spit out in the JSON that comes from the staking-cli as the validator "public key". Another public/private pair that is the withdrawal pair. The hash of the public part of this latter pair is the "withdrawal credentials" in that JSON from the staking-cli. Staked.us uses the first pair, namely the public/private validating key, as the second pair for their customers.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I can't find anything of the sort on their website. It says:

> Stakedâ€™s ETH2 offering is non-custodial, meaning only you (the depositor) has access to the withdrawal address key pair required to withdraw in Phase 1 and onwards. Without this key funds cannot be withdrawn so it is extremely important to keep it safe. 

And whatever they actually do is also beside the point. I'm saying that whomever is in control of the withdrawal credentials should have the ability to exit, and that this comes without loss of trust. I can only see it helping with e.g. avoiding staking service providers keeping funds hostage.

I can't think of any situation where "withdrawal credentials + exit ability" leads to e.g. stealing of funds compared to just "withdrawal credentials".

author: pietjepuk
content:
Worst I can think of (and not sure if this is even possible) is if the owner of some hypothetical smoothing/pooling contract can send mass exit messages for all validators using it. Can't steal funds, can't really disrupt the beacon chain either, but can fill up the exit queue.

(I guess not possible, because smart contracts don't have a private key associated with their address right?)

author: jgm
content: The thing is, it has been clear from genesis that the holder of the withdrawal credentials does *not* have the ability to exit.  A change to this, in my opinion, would require a situation that was unanticipated from the phase0 specification to be worth considering.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Yes, agree that that's what was stated. But that surely can't be a reason _not_ to change it in and of itself. If there are no negative consequences to adding it, I don't see why not add it like many other things that have changed or will change since genesis.

And I'm not saying it's high priority or anything close to it. And as far "something unanticipated"; I for one did not think that pre-signed exit messages would expire, does that count? ðŸ˜‰

author: jgm
content:
Yes, I think that it is a reason not to change it.

A possible negative consequence: validator service X provided validating services on the basis that they would be paid once withdrawals were available.  They could guarantee this by holding the validator keys from the users, and this change would allow the user to walk away from the service without paying.

Not saying that this is a real consequence, as I'm unaware of anyone that offers services on this basis.  But it's possible that they are, and we don't know about it.

Everyone who staked did so with an understanding of what the protocol did and did not allow (and, to a lesser extent, what was expected to arrive in the future).  I'm uncomfortable with significant changes to the spec like this without a compelling reason.
